title: Australia's most powerful directors revealed
text:
“It is really important that boards set aside enough time to consider the substantial matters of the day, such as the disruption caused by technology, the future of work, and the importance of a slowing economy,” Maxsted says.

This theme is picked up in the BOSS director roundtable where Graham Bradley, chairman of the Australian arm of British bank HSBC, Virgin Australia International, EnergyAustralia and grain storage company GrainCorp, says that stepping back to examine strategy is a constant challenge. “Risk reporting has now become so onerous and voluminous that it often takes your thinking away from the real things that can go wrong and the real opportunities we should be pursuing.”

Graham Bradley says stepping back to examine strategy is a constant challenge. Cole Bennetts

Yasmin Allen, a director of ASX, Cochlear and Santos, says the challenge is to push enough work to committees to enable boards to “lift our heads up and think long term”.

Zlatko Todorcevski, a director at cement maker Adelaide Brighton, casino operator Star Entertainment and Coles, reveals that several of his boards add three days to their annual board meetings to “focus on strategy with nothing else”.

Livingstone puts the macro economy and geopolitical threats at the top of her list of issues, followed by product innovation, culture, remuneration and cyber security.

Woodside’s Goyder puts climate change on his agenda, along with community issues such as “true” Indigenous reconciliation, as well as investing in the communities where Woodside operates.

Returns are the 'foundation block'

However, the former Wesfarmers CEO says those challenges need to be built on the “foundation block of generating sustainable returns so that people can be employed, taxes paid, and all stakeholders [shareholders, employees, suppliers, community, environment] benefit”.

Lendlease chairman Michael Ullmer’s main issues are energy, regulators and a lack of productivity improvements, and he says much of the blame lies with government.

Advertisement

“The cost of energy is challenging the viability of a number of business models,” he says. He also warns about a contradiction in the government’s rhetoric that business should get out and invest while its default option is to encourage regulators to litigate.

“Choices on where to invest capital will be impacted by the uncertainty in policy and regulatory frameworks.”

Another of his top concerns is the lack of progress on the productivity agenda for more than a decade.

'This is one of the most challenging issues'

Many top directors nominated culture as an issue of growing importance, with the main concern being how to find the best way to measure it.

“This is one of the most challenging issues facing boards today,” says Australia Post, Woolworths and Abacus Property director Holly Kramer. “We need to find better ways to monitor organisational culture other than by relying on the outdated employee engagement surveys.”

Commonwealth Bank director Catherine Livingstone warns the best HR policies in the world become meaningless if they are not followed in practice. Edwina Pickles

Ullmer agrees: “Make sure that culture is a core topic on the board agenda, and establish ways to regularly measure it.”

Carnival Australia chairman Ann Sherry says: “Culture measures are weak and varied [and] investors discount as a result. Organisations pick and choose. [There] needs to be greater discipline about measurement and then accountability.”

Livingstone, who has kept a low profile over the past 12 months, says boards need to distinguish between the infrastructure side of culture (policies, processes and systems) and its human side (the lived experience of the traditions, beliefs and symbols that characterise the organisation).

Advertisement

“It is the interaction between these two dimensions which determines the overall culture of an organisation.”

Livingstone, who was at the centre of the maelstrom from the Hayne royal commission, warns the best HR policies in the world become meaningless if they are not followed in practice.

“A strong human side of culture can be undermined by policies, processes and systems which are not fit for purpose and which therefore undermine the ability of employees to get their job done without, for example, resorting to workarounds,” she says. “These workarounds can have unintended risk consequences, and hence a perception of poor culture.”

'We have lost our way a bit' on pay

Executive pay remains deeply divisive for boards, and confusion reigns over how it can be simplified. The debate intensified following the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority’s (APRA) push to make bank pay based on 50 per cent non-financial risks, which is controversial with investors.

“I think we have lost our way a bit on executive remuneration,” Goyder says. “The time taken by boards and remuneration committees on executive remuneration is out of whack with its importance.”

Goyder says the quality of management, employees and the board, the balance sheet, cash generation, and capacity to take opportunities and withstand shocks should be the key drivers for investors and stakeholders. “I hope that we eventually get to more simplified remuneration models, with base salary and equity earned over time the key components.”

Others agree the answer is more simplified base pay and long-term incentives, which are better aligned to investors. Newcrest Mining chairman Peter Hay suggests “an incremental change towards long-term, equity-based rem”, as does Ansell’s Glenn Barnes, who says: “Drop short-term incentives and move to salary package plus long-term options.”

Maxsted also suggests replacing long-term incentive schemes with share rights, “which provide a much better alignment between shareholder and executive”.

Advertisement

Safe Work Australia chairman and Wesfarmers and AGL director Diane Smith-Gander says ultimately it is as simple as boards having “more courage to reduce absolute remuneration levels”.

'You can’t take a punt on people'

Boards are looking at themselves more closely than ever, as they have come under heavy fire following the Hayne royal commission and the APRA report into CBA, which warned that the bank board had a “light hand on the tiller”.

As boards dive deeper into management, they are also grappling with how much they should wade into "social activism" amid growing criticism of the so-called directors’ club and the push for greater gender and cultural diversity.

Maxsted firmly believes a lot of the issues come back to an expectation gap about the role of boards, and says that while watching the ousting of NAB chairman Ken Henry, he experienced “an element of there but for the grace of God”.

“A lot of people are confusing the role of board member versus management, either mischievously or because they don’t understand,” the former KPMG accountant says, likening the public’s expectation gap to the role of auditors. “When there are issues as evidenced by Hayne, the immediate focus goes straight to the board. What was the board doing? Was the board asleep? Why wasn’t it thinking about this?”

The obligation is very clear in the law. My primary bligation is to the shareholders. — Lindsay Maxsted, Westpac chairman

Maxsted has some sympathy for Gerry Harvey and David Murray, who believe there is too much focus on diversity, although he agrees they are at the “extreme” end of the debate.

“Quite clearly, the principal job of the board is to plenish yourself with the right skill set … part of the way in which the board will work best is if there is diversity on the board, so the two aren’t against each other. Gerry is right that, at the end of the day, you’ve got to get the right people who understand the business and can make a really strong contribution.”

Advertisement

Maxsted, to an extent, also defends the directors’ club. “It’s like everything: if you want the best people in terms of their qualifications, part of their qualifications will be experience doing something. These are really important jobs and you can’t take a punt on people from different backgrounds who haven’t had experience sitting around a board table all the time … I’ve got people on my Westpac and Transurban boards where it’s their first board appointment, but you can’t have too many of them.”

Maxsted also has a conventional take on directors’ duties, amid continued debate about whether boards could be made to consider social and environmental concerns.

“The obligation is very clear in the law,” he says. “My primary obligation is to the shareholders,” which he says allows some flexibility to consider customers and broader stakeholders.

The wild card in the debate among directors is a changing of the guard, as shown by the BOSS analysis. This is partly being driven by the normal fluctuations of the market, but also by a younger set of chairmen and directors taking power.

While Maxsted remains on top of the power ranking, and a clutch of female directors have climbed this year, others such as AMP directors David Murray, John O’Sullivan, John Fraser and Peter Varghese have dropped since 2017 as the financial sector, and AMP in particular, waned.

ANZ directors including chairman David Gonski, Jane Halton (also on Crown), Paula Dwyer, John Key, Ilana Atlas, Graeme Liebelt and John Macfarlane also fell down the list as bank stocks suffered.

There is also a cohort of younger chairmen and directors stepping into key roles. Those include MacKenzie at BHP, Goyder at Woodside, Atlas at Coca-Cola Amatil, Tim Poole at Aurizon Holdings and Simon Thompson at Rio Tinto.

A recent survey of top-50 CEOs found their average age has fallen to 54, signalling a shift from the Baby Boomers to Generation X.

Long-time director Rebecca McGrath says this changing of the guard “implies a change in attitude, style and behaviour”, and perhaps signals a greater emphasis on social and environmental issues such as diversity, inclusion, climate change and workplace culture.
description: Lindsay Maxsted, the chairman of Westpac and roads operator Transurban has again topped the AFR BOSS magazine list of most powerful directors. There's also been an influx of women at the top. Here's who else made the cut.
